page.title: 07THE NATIONAL STUD
page.content: In 1915 Col. Hall Walker MP offered his bloodstock at Tully in Ireland to the British Government for the purpose of ounding a national stud. In 1963 the horse racing Betting Levy Board was responsible for the operation and control of the National Stud and the buildings in Newmarket were opened by the Queen in 1967. The day to day running of the stud requires a staff of about 30 and students are accepted to learn stud management. The purpose of the stud is for breeding top class horses. The covering season starts in the spring, traditionally on St Valentine's day and the gestation period is for 11 months. Foals are normally born soon after January 1st and all horses have their birthdays on this day. The horses train every day but Sunday. The stud's offspring include; Mill Reef,Grundy,Royal Palace
